metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are users in HealthRules Payer and their roles and permissions. The section explains that a user is a person who uses any of the HealthRules Payer applications and must have an account. Users can be individuals or in specific roles, and they must be assigned a unique username and password combination. Each user must also be a member of a group to have the necessary permissions to access the application. The section also mentions the required HealthRules users and groups.

__data__.text: UsersSkip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: UsersIn HealthRules Payer, a user is a person who uses any of the HealthRules Payer applications (Manager, Designer, and Administration Console) and must have an account. A user can be a specific individual, such as John Smith, a person in a particular role, such as Account Repair, or a special system user required by HealthRules to run specific processes. The administrator must assign each user a unique user name and password combination. Each user must be a member of a group, that is, be a part of at least one group to have the necessary permissions to access the application (see "Required HealthRules Users and Groups").				askHE			Disclaimer					askHE utilizes generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and is intended to provide general information. metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are groups and user access control. A group is a record containing a list of users and other groups, and it helps control user access to the system through the assignment of permissions. Groups can belong to one or more other groups, forming a hierarchical chain. The section also mentions the use of groups to assign a set of permissions for similar types of users. The entities mentioned in the section are users, groups, and permissions.

__data__.text: GroupsSkip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: GroupsA group is a record containing a list of users and other groups. Groups help control user access to the system through the assignment of permissions. A group can belong to one or more other groups, forming a hierarchical chain of groups. metadata.section_summary: The key topics of this section are permissions in HealthRules Payer, the types of permissions (direct and indirect), and the different categories of permissions available. The entities mentioned include user groups, user access to actions, claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.

__data__.text: PermissionsSkip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: PermissionsThe permissions allows you to manage user access to HealthRules Payer actions (such as view, create, and amend), claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.Permissions are assigned to groups and not users. Permissions are always granted (not restricted) in a group and are additive as you move down the chain of hierarchical groups. In other words, the more groups you belong to, the more permissions (greater access) you have. Users inherit permissions from the group to which they belong. When a user does not have permission for a feature, the system hides or disables that part of the application.There are two types of permissions:Direct Permissions: These are permissions set up within a group. You can change these permissions from within the group record.Indirect Permissions: These are inherited from other groups and are also known as inherited permissions. Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed in a group record and can be changed only by going directly to the group record in the hierarchy that contains the permissions.When upgrading HealthRules Payer applications, new permissions (typically added to support new features) are assigned only to the "hcc_super_user" group. You need to specifically assign any new permissions included in the upgrade to the other appropriate group or groups. Also, if you add or change permissions while the applications are in use, you must restart the application before the permission changes take effect.The table below describes the permission categories available in HealthRules.Permission TypeDescriptionType Action PermissionsDefines which actions are permitted (view, create, amend, etc.) for a document type (account, subscription, supplier, etc.) by the group members (see "Appendix A: Permission Sets").Claim Processing PermissionsDefines the claim actions permitted (view, enter, reprocess, review, repair, etc.) for the members of the group. You can vary the permissions for selected claim actions by the claim sources listed below (see "Creating a Group").AdjustInput — This permission grants the ability to open a finalized claim for edit.AdjustOutput — This permission grants the ability to adjust financials on a finalized claim.Review — This permission grants the ability to open a claim in a review state to edit and adjust the financials. It also allows the user to deny the claim and approve review conditions (further controlled by message code permissions).Repair — This permission grants the ability to open a claim in a repair state to edit or reject a claim.Void — This permission grants the ability to manually void a claim that should never have existed. For more information, see the Vol. 8: Claims chapter in the HealthRules Payer Manager’s Guide.Replace — This permission grants the ability to replace a previously entered claim with incorrect or missing information.You can also set the claim reprocessing override permission (allow or disallow) and the maximum amount group members can approve to pay on a claim from the Claim Review and Repair Workbasket. Message Code PermissionsDefines the message codes that members of the group have permission to work. The members of the group can access the transactions associated with the selected message codes in the workbaskets to review or repair.This can be all codes for every message type or a specific message type and code combination.Override Denial Message Code PermissionsDefines the denial message codes members of the group can manually override or add to a claim line.Group Access PermissionsDefines the permissions to access member-related data in a unit within a line of business (LOB). These include carriers, business segments, accounts, or products.Sensitive Data PermissionsDefines the attributes protected by sensitive data rules that the members of the group can access. The sensitive data rules apply to subscription, membership, claim or service authorization attributes and are defined via the sensitive data rule setting in HealthRules Designer.For example, if a sensitive data rule is defined for member salary amounts or social security numbers, then you must grant access to the field by assigning this permission to view the actual value, or else the value is masked and cannot be viewed.ID Restriction PermissionsDefines the document types where the ID cannot be entered or edited manually. When applied to the following document types, the system will automatically generate the ID based on the ID generation rules and be read-only.Subscription ID /Member ID Account IDSupplier ID Practitioner IDService Authorization ID Supplier Location IDPractitioner Role NameClaim IDNote: This permission type differs from other permission types in that it prevents users from taking action, while other permission types allow an action.Report PermissionsDefines the HealthRules Answers reports members of the group can view or execute.Advanced PermissionsDefines the following special advanced permissions the members of the group have.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are permissions in the HealthRules Payer system. It discusses different types of permissions, such as report permissions and advanced permissions. It also explains the concept of VIP permissions and how they are inherited through a hierarchical structure. The section provides tips for working with permissions, including the importance of planning the group/permissions hierarchy and the additive nature of permissions. The entities mentioned in the section include Subscription ID, Member ID, Account ID, Supplier ID, Practitioner ID, Service Authorization ID, Supplier Location ID, Practitioner Role Name, and Claim ID.

__data__.text: When applied to the following document types, the system will automatically generate the ID based on the ID generation rules and be read-only.Subscription ID /Member ID Account IDSupplier ID Practitioner IDService Authorization ID Supplier Location IDPractitioner Role NameClaim IDNote: This permission type differs from other permission types in that it prevents users from taking action, while other permission types allow an action.Report PermissionsDefines the HealthRules Answers reports members of the group can view or execute.Advanced PermissionsDefines the following special advanced permissions the members of the group have. VIP permissions — This allows members of the group to view records flagged as VIP records using the hierarchical structure described below. Users without VIP permission cannot search or view any records with VIP restrictions.Account — Sub-accounts automatically inherit VIP permissions from the parent account. Therefore, if the VIP restriction is for the account document type and the user has the VIP permission, the user can view all sub-account, subscription, and member records flagged as VIP.Account — Sub-accounts automatically inherit VIP permissions from the parent account. Therefore, if the VIP restriction is for the account document type and the user has the VIP permission, the user can view all sub-account, subscription, and member records flagged as VIP.Trusted User Permission  — Allows members of the group to interact between HealthRules Payer and HealthRules Portal/third-party products. Typically, only the groups “portal_group” and “hcc_integration_group” have this permission.Note: This should only be granted to the portal_group (see "Required HealthRules Users and Groups").Supervisor group permissions  — Allows members of these groups the ability to assign or multi-assign items to a workbasket. Note that the supervisor permission also automatically grants users VIP permission.Answers Publishing Wizards permissions — For Answers 2.X only, it specifies whether group members can use the HealthRules Answers publishing wizard to upload, configure and delete custom reports. For more information see the HealthRules Answers User Guide.Note: The Answers Publishing function is for Answers 2.X only. Answers 3.X does not use this function.Tips about permissionsHere are some key points to remember when working with permissions:Always write down and model your group/permissions hierarchy on paper (or in a tool like Visio) before creating groups and permissions in HealthRules Payer — you need to think through the overall structure before creating groups. Example The following illustration shows how permissions are granted to users in an additive fashion as they are inherited through a hierarchy of groups:The above graphic illustrates how the permission hierarchy can be visualized as an inverted (upside down) organizational chart. As you move down the hierarchy more and more permissions are granted to more senior roles (fewer users), which require fuller access to the system.VIP permissions and Group Access Account permissions inherit permissions from the top account in the top account-sub account structure. As a result, if a member has access to a record in a top account but not at the subaccount level, the member can view the record from the top account. Please note that this inheritance does not apply to Workbasket Assignment Exclusion permissions.Example The following illustration shows how the HealthRules system uses a hierarchical structure to grant VIP permissions to users. For example, since VIP permissions are at the top-account level, members in that account inherits the same VIP permissions. Therefore, if a user is assigned VIP permissions, the user can view VIP records from account level to the member level. The top-level permission always overrides the lower level permissions. Therefore in the following example, if VIP permissions are also set on the subscription B, members of that subscription will still inherit VIP permissions from the top account. Groups with access to the  top account, business segment, or carrier can access the documents related to the sub-accounts.Permissions always grant access to an application or feature (the only two exceptions are the ability to limit Carrier, Business Segment, Account or Product access).Basic permissions should be granted to the top-level group/groups. The Single Permission group in the diagram below depicts how basic permissions are granted.Permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets long, more and more permissions are granted. Because permissions are always additive from one group to another, there are no overriding or superseding permissions from lower-level to higher-level groups.Permissions are always granted to groups, not individual users. A user must belong to a group or groups to have permission.Groups inherit permissions when they are members of other groups.Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are permissions and groups in the HealthRules Payer application. It explains that permissions grant access to applications or features and are always granted to groups, not individual users. The section also mentions that permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets longer, more permissions are granted. It highlights that permissions are inherited by groups when they are members of other groups, and inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed. The section concludes by mentioning that permissions are cached in memory and if they are changed, the user must exit and restart the HealthRules Payer clients to pick up the updated permissions.

__data__.text: Groups with access to the  top account, business segment, or carrier can access the documents related to the sub-accounts.Permissions always grant access to an application or feature (the only two exceptions are the ability to limit Carrier, Business Segment, Account or Product access).Basic permissions should be granted to the top-level group/groups. The Single Permission group in the diagram below depicts how basic permissions are granted.Permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets long, more and more permissions are granted. Because permissions are always additive from one group to another, there are no overriding or superseding permissions from lower-level to higher-level groups.Permissions are always granted to groups, not individual users. A user must belong to a group or groups to have permission.Groups inherit permissions when they are members of other groups.Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed. You must view them as direct permissions in the appropriate parent group and, if necessary, remove them from the group from which it inherits the permissions.All members must inherit permissions directly or indirectly from the "hcc_user" group because this is the only group that authenticates users for logging. All other groups grant permissions to applications/features.Permissions are cached in memory when the user logs on to the application. Therefore, if permissions are changed, a user must exit and re-start the HealthRules Payer clients (Manager and Designer) to pick up the changed permissions.				askHE			Disclaimer					askHE utilizes generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and is intended to provide general information. When applied to the following document types, the system will automatically generate the ID based on the ID generation rules and be read-only.Subscription ID /Member ID Account IDSupplier ID Practitioner IDService Authorization ID Supplier Location IDPractitioner Role NameClaim IDNote: This permission type differs from other permission types in that it prevents users from taking action, while other permission types allow an action.Report PermissionsDefines the HealthRules Answers reports members of the group can view or execute.Advanced PermissionsDefines the following special advanced permissions the members of the group have.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are permissions in the HealthRules Payer system. It discusses different types of permissions, such as report permissions and advanced permissions. It also explains the concept of VIP permissions and how they are inherited through a hierarchical structure. The section provides tips for working with permissions, including the importance of planning the group/permissions hierarchy and the additive nature of permissions. The entities mentioned in the section include Subscription ID, Member ID, Account ID, Supplier ID, Practitioner ID, Service Authorization ID, Supplier Location ID, Practitioner Role Name, and Claim ID.

__data__.text: When applied to the following document types, the system will automatically generate the ID based on the ID generation rules and be read-only.Subscription ID /Member ID Account IDSupplier ID Practitioner IDService Authorization ID Supplier Location IDPractitioner Role NameClaim IDNote: This permission type differs from other permission types in that it prevents users from taking action, while other permission types allow an action.Report PermissionsDefines the HealthRules Answers reports members of the group can view or execute.Advanced PermissionsDefines the following special advanced permissions the members of the group have. VIP permissions — This allows members of the group to view records flagged as VIP records using the hierarchical structure described below. Users without VIP permission cannot search or view any records with VIP restrictions.Account — Sub-accounts automatically inherit VIP permissions from the parent account. Therefore, if the VIP restriction is for the account document type and the user has the VIP permission, the user can view all sub-account, subscription, and member records flagged as VIP.Account — Sub-accounts automatically inherit VIP permissions from the parent account. Therefore, if the VIP restriction is for the account document type and the user has the VIP permission, the user can view all sub-account, subscription, and member records flagged as VIP.Trusted User Permission  — Allows members of the group to interact between HealthRules Payer and HealthRules Portal/third-party products. Typically, only the groups “portal_group” and “hcc_integration_group” have this permission.Note: This should only be granted to the portal_group (see "Required HealthRules Users and Groups").Supervisor group permissions  — Allows members of these groups the ability to assign or multi-assign items to a workbasket. Note that the supervisor permission also automatically grants users VIP permission.Answers Publishing Wizards permissions — For Answers 2.X only, it specifies whether group members can use the HealthRules Answers publishing wizard to upload, configure and delete custom reports. For more information see the HealthRules Answers User Guide.Note: The Answers Publishing function is for Answers 2.X only. Answers 3.X does not use this function.Tips about permissionsHere are some key points to remember when working with permissions:Always write down and model your group/permissions hierarchy on paper (or in a tool like Visio) before creating groups and permissions in HealthRules Payer — you need to think through the overall structure before creating groups. Example The following illustration shows how permissions are granted to users in an additive fashion as they are inherited through a hierarchy of groups:The above graphic illustrates how the permission hierarchy can be visualized as an inverted (upside down) organizational chart. As you move down the hierarchy more and more permissions are granted to more senior roles (fewer users), which require fuller access to the system.VIP permissions and Group Access Account permissions inherit permissions from the top account in the top account-sub account structure. As a result, if a member has access to a record in a top account but not at the subaccount level, the member can view the record from the top account. Please note that this inheritance does not apply to Workbasket Assignment Exclusion permissions.Example The following illustration shows how the HealthRules system uses a hierarchical structure to grant VIP permissions to users. For example, since VIP permissions are at the top-account level, members in that account inherits the same VIP permissions. Therefore, if a user is assigned VIP permissions, the user can view VIP records from account level to the member level. The top-level permission always overrides the lower level permissions. Therefore in the following example, if VIP permissions are also set on the subscription B, members of that subscription will still inherit VIP permissions from the top account. Groups with access to the  top account, business segment, or carrier can access the documents related to the sub-accounts.Permissions always grant access to an application or feature (the only two exceptions are the ability to limit Carrier, Business Segment, Account or Product access).Basic permissions should be granted to the top-level group/groups. The Single Permission group in the diagram below depicts how basic permissions are granted.Permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets long, more and more permissions are granted. Because permissions are always additive from one group to another, there are no overriding or superseding permissions from lower-level to higher-level groups.Permissions are always granted to groups, not individual users. A user must belong to a group or groups to have permission.Groups inherit permissions when they are members of other groups.Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are permissions and groups in the HealthRules Payer application. It explains that permissions grant access to applications or features and are always granted to groups, not individual users. The section also mentions that permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets longer, more permissions are granted. It highlights that permissions are inherited by groups when they are members of other groups, and inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed. The section concludes by mentioning that permissions are cached in memory and if they are changed, the user must exit and restart the HealthRules Payer clients to pick up the updated permissions.

__data__.text: Groups with access to the  top account, business segment, or carrier can access the documents related to the sub-accounts.Permissions always grant access to an application or feature (the only two exceptions are the ability to limit Carrier, Business Segment, Account or Product access).Basic permissions should be granted to the top-level group/groups. The Single Permission group in the diagram below depicts how basic permissions are granted.Permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets long, more and more permissions are granted. Because permissions are always additive from one group to another, there are no overriding or superseding permissions from lower-level to higher-level groups.Permissions are always granted to groups, not individual users. A user must belong to a group or groups to have permission.Groups inherit permissions when they are members of other groups.Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed. You must view them as direct permissions in the appropriate parent group and, if necessary, remove them from the group from which it inherits the permissions.All members must inherit permissions directly or indirectly from the "hcc_user" group because this is the only group that authenticates users for logging. All other groups grant permissions to applications/features.Permissions are cached in memory when the user logs on to the application. Therefore, if permissions are changed, a user must exit and re-start the HealthRules Payer clients (Manager and Designer) to pick up the changed permissions.				askHE			Disclaimer					askHE utilizes generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and is intended to provide general information. metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are the required HealthRules users and groups. The section provides a list of the users and their descriptions, as well as the groups they are a part of in HealthRules Payer. The section also lists the required HealthRules groups and their descriptions. The entities mentioned in the section include the HealthRules users (such as hcc_admin and portal) and the HealthRules groups (such as hcc_user and hcc_admin_group).

__data__.text: Required HealthRules Users and GroupsSkip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: Required HealthRules Users and GroupsThe following HealthRules users and groups are set up in HealthRules (stored in the HealthRules OLTP database), either through the HealthRules Administration Console or imported with the help of HealthEdge Professional Services. These users are assigned to one or more groups (have a membership) to inherit the permissions necessary to log on to the HealthRules Payer application and access its various features.If you use layered external authentication, it is important to understand the impact that layered authentication has on users and groups in HealthRules. For more information, see the HealthRules Payer Reduced Sign-On Guide.Required HealthRules UsersThe following table lists the users, a description of the user, and the groups the members are a part of in HealthRules Payer. User NameDescriptionMust be a Member of Grouphcc_adminDefault user with administrator privileges. This user performs administration and user management tasks. User “hcc_admin” is included in the Administrator Console when you install it. Note: The password associated with the “hcc_admin” user account is the default system password. Normally, this password should not be changed. If you need to change it, you will need to perform additional steps beyond a normal password change (see . "Changing a User Password").hcc_admin_grouphcc_super_user**For Professional Services deployments, do not make the hcc_admin user a member of the hcc_super_user group.hcc_transact_admin_groupflux_admin_groupportalThis is a special “system user” that provides connectivity between the HealthRules applications and the HealthRules Portal.No one should sign on using this system user account.Note: When the password for the “portal” user is changed, the OltpPassword property in the HealthRules Portal application’s web.config file must also be set.portal_groupintegrationThe default user for third-party system integrations. This user performs administration and user management tasks associated with integrating third-party systems with HealthRules Payer. The user “integration” is included in the default server installation and will appear in the HealthRules Administration Console after installing HealthRules Payer.hcc_integration_groupsystemThis is a special “system user” that executes background server processes, such as scheduled jobs.No one should sign on using this system user account. flux_admin_grouphcc_super_userRequired HealthRules GroupsThe following table lists the groups, a description of the group, and the groups the members are a part of in HealthRules Payer.You do not have to create these groups. These are out-of-the-box groups included in the default server installation and will appear in the HealthRules Administration Console after installing HealthRules Payer.Group NameDescriptionMust be a Member of Grouphcc_userNote that this is a group, not a user. This group provides the required authentication to log on to HealthRules Payer and does not provide business permissions. Other groups provide authorization to access various HealthRules Payer features. Because membership in this group is required to log on to Health Rules Payer, all users must belong to this group either directly or indirectly. However, this group does not have to be a part of other groups.NAhcc_admin_groupThis group provides access to the HealthRules Administration Console.Users belonging to this group are responsible for password security configuration and managing users ad group permissions.hcc_userhcc_super_userNote that this is a group, not a user. This group is granted all permissions. Whenever new permissions are included in a new HealthRules Payer release or upgrade, the new permissions are automatically added to this group so that at least one group can access the new feature. Therefore, members who are allowed to make all system changes should be members of this group.Note: This group will always have all required permissions by default. Manual changes are not recommended.hcc_userhcc_transact_admin_groupThis group provides access to the Transaction Management window.Only users who need access to Transaction Manager in HealthRules Manager should be a member of this group.NA flux_admin_groupMany HealthRules Payer customers use the Flux job scheduler by the Flux Corporation to schedule and automatically execute billing runs, payment runs, and other operations. When the Flux scheduler is used to run these jobs, the required permissions need to be set up in this group. NAhcc_integration_groupThis group provides access permissions for the “integration” user.Users belonging to this group are responsible for third-party systems integration.You do not have to create this group.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of this section are permissions in HealthRules Payer, the types of permissions (direct and indirect), and the different categories of permissions available. The entities mentioned include user groups, user access to actions, claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.

__data__.text: PermissionsSkip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: PermissionsThe permissions allows you to manage user access to HealthRules Payer actions (such as view, create, and amend), claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.Permissions are assigned to groups and not users. Permissions are always granted (not restricted) in a group and are additive as you move down the chain of hierarchical groups. In other words, the more groups you belong to, the more permissions (greater access) you have. Users inherit permissions from the group to which they belong. When a user does not have permission for a feature, the system hides or disables that part of the application.There are two types of permissions:Direct Permissions: These are permissions set up within a group. You can change these permissions from within the group record.Indirect Permissions: These are inherited from other groups and are also known as inherited permissions. Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed in a group record and can be changed only by going directly to the group record in the hierarchy that contains the permissions.When upgrading HealthRules Payer applications, new permissions (typically added to support new features) are assigned only to the "hcc_super_user" group. You need to specifically assign any new permissions included in the upgrade to the other appropriate group or groups. Also, if you add or change permissions while the applications are in use, you must restart the application before the permission changes take effect.The table below describes the permission categories available in HealthRules.Permission TypeDescriptionType Action PermissionsDefines which actions are permitted (view, create, amend, etc.) for a document type (account, subscription, supplier, etc.) by the group members (see "Appendix A: Permission Sets").Claim Processing PermissionsDefines the claim actions permitted (view, enter, reprocess, review, repair, etc.) for the members of the group. You can vary the permissions for selected claim actions by the claim sources listed below (see "Creating a Group").AdjustInput — This permission grants the ability to open a finalized claim for edit.AdjustOutput — This permission grants the ability to adjust financials on a finalized claim.Review — This permission grants the ability to open a claim in a review state to edit and adjust the financials. It also allows the user to deny the claim and approve review conditions (further controlled by message code permissions).Repair — This permission grants the ability to open a claim in a repair state to edit or reject a claim.Void — This permission grants the ability to manually void a claim that should never have existed. For more information, see the Vol. 8: Claims chapter in the HealthRules Payer Manager’s Guide.Replace — This permission grants the ability to replace a previously entered claim with incorrect or missing information.You can also set the claim reprocessing override permission (allow or disallow) and the maximum amount group members can approve to pay on a claim from the Claim Review and Repair Workbasket. Message Code PermissionsDefines the message codes that members of the group have permission to work. The members of the group can access the transactions associated with the selected message codes in the workbaskets to review or repair.This can be all codes for every message type or a specific message type and code combination.Override Denial Message Code PermissionsDefines the denial message codes members of the group can manually override or add to a claim line.Group Access PermissionsDefines the permissions to access member-related data in a unit within a line of business (LOB). These include carriers, business segments, accounts, or products.Sensitive Data PermissionsDefines the attributes protected by sensitive data rules that the members of the group can access. The sensitive data rules apply to subscription, membership, claim or service authorization attributes and are defined via the sensitive data rule setting in HealthRules Designer.For example, if a sensitive data rule is defined for member salary amounts or social security numbers, then you must grant access to the field by assigning this permission to view the actual value, or else the value is masked and cannot be viewed.ID Restriction PermissionsDefines the document types where the ID cannot be entered or edited manually. When applied to the following document types, the system will automatically generate the ID based on the ID generation rules and be read-only.Subscription ID /Member ID Account IDSupplier ID Practitioner IDService Authorization ID Supplier Location IDPractitioner Role NameClaim IDNote: This permission type differs from other permission types in that it prevents users from taking action, while other permission types allow an action.Report PermissionsDefines the HealthRules Answers reports members of the group can view or execute.Advanced PermissionsDefines the following special advanced permissions the members of the group have.

The section provides tips for working with permissions, including the importance of planning the group/permissions hierarchy and the additive nature of permissions. The entities mentioned in the section include Subscription ID, Member ID, Account ID, Supplier ID, Practitioner ID, Service Authorization ID, Supplier Location ID, Practitioner Role Name, and Claim ID.

__data__.text: When applied to the following document types, the system will automatically generate the ID based on the ID generation rules and be read-only.Subscription ID /Member ID Account IDSupplier ID Practitioner IDService Authorization ID Supplier Location IDPractitioner Role NameClaim IDNote: This permission type differs from other permission types in that it prevents users from taking action, while other permission types allow an action.Report PermissionsDefines the HealthRules Answers reports members of the group can view or execute.Advanced PermissionsDefines the following special advanced permissions the members of the group have. VIP permissions — This allows members of the group to view records flagged as VIP records using the hierarchical structure described below. Users without VIP permission cannot search or view any records with VIP restrictions.Account — Sub-accounts automatically inherit VIP permissions from the parent account. Therefore, if the VIP restriction is for the account document type and the user has the VIP permission, the user can view all sub-account, subscription, and member records flagged as VIP.Account — Sub-accounts automatically inherit VIP permissions from the parent account. Therefore, if the VIP restriction is for the account document type and the user has the VIP permission, the user can view all sub-account, subscription, and member records flagged as VIP.Trusted User Permission  — Allows members of the group to interact between HealthRules Payer and HealthRules Portal/third-party products. Typically, only the groups “portal_group” and “hcc_integration_group” have this permission.Note: This should only be granted to the portal_group (see "Required HealthRules Users and Groups").Supervisor group permissions  — Allows members of these groups the ability to assign or multi-assign items to a workbasket. Note that the supervisor permission also automatically grants users VIP permission.Answers Publishing Wizards permissions — For Answers 2.X only, it specifies whether group members can use the HealthRules Answers publishing wizard to upload, configure and delete custom reports. For more information see the HealthRules Answers User Guide.Note: The Answers Publishing function is for Answers 2.X only. Answers 3.X does not use this function.Tips about permissionsHere are some key points to remember when working with permissions:Always write down and model your group/permissions hierarchy on paper (or in a tool like Visio) before creating groups and permissions in HealthRules Payer — you need to think through the overall structure before creating groups. Example The following illustration shows how permissions are granted to users in an additive fashion as they are inherited through a hierarchy of groups:The above graphic illustrates how the permission hierarchy can be visualized as an inverted (upside down) organizational chart. As you move down the hierarchy more and more permissions are granted to more senior roles (fewer users), which require fuller access to the system.VIP permissions and Group Access Account permissions inherit permissions from the top account in the top account-sub account structure. As a result, if a member has access to a record in a top account but not at the subaccount level, the member can view the record from the top account. Please note that this inheritance does not apply to Workbasket Assignment Exclusion permissions.Example The following illustration shows how the HealthRules system uses a hierarchical structure to grant VIP permissions to users. For example, since VIP permissions are at the top-account level, members in that account inherits the same VIP permissions. Therefore, if a user is assigned VIP permissions, the user can view VIP records from account level to the member level. The top-level permission always overrides the lower level permissions. Therefore in the following example, if VIP permissions are also set on the subscription B, members of that subscription will still inherit VIP permissions from the top account. Groups with access to the  top account, business segment, or carrier can access the documents related to the sub-accounts.Permissions always grant access to an application or feature (the only two exceptions are the ability to limit Carrier, Business Segment, Account or Product access).Basic permissions should be granted to the top-level group/groups. The Single Permission group in the diagram below depicts how basic permissions are granted.Permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets long, more and more permissions are granted. Because permissions are always additive from one group to another, there are no overriding or superseding permissions from lower-level to higher-level groups.Permissions are always granted to groups, not individual users. A user must belong to a group or groups to have permission.Groups inherit permissions when they are members of other groups.Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are permissions and groups in the HealthRules Payer application. It explains that permissions grant access to applications or features and are always granted to groups, not individual users. The section also mentions that permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets longer, more permissions are granted. It highlights that permissions are inherited by groups when they are members of other groups, and inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed. The section concludes by mentioning that permissions are cached in memory and if they are changed, the user must exit and restart the HealthRules Payer clients to pick up the updated permissions.

__data__.text: Groups with access to the  top account, business segment, or carrier can access the documents related to the sub-accounts.Permissions always grant access to an application or feature (the only two exceptions are the ability to limit Carrier, Business Segment, Account or Product access).Basic permissions should be granted to the top-level group/groups. The Single Permission group in the diagram below depicts how basic permissions are granted.Permissions are additive, meaning that as the hierarchical chain of groups gets long, more and more permissions are granted. Because permissions are always additive from one group to another, there are no overriding or superseding permissions from lower-level to higher-level groups.Permissions are always granted to groups, not individual users. A user must belong to a group or groups to have permission.Groups inherit permissions when they are members of other groups.Inherited permissions cannot be viewed or changed. You must view them as direct permissions in the appropriate parent group and, if necessary, remove them from the group from which it inherits the permissions.All members must inherit permissions directly or indirectly from the "hcc_user" group because this is the only group that authenticates users for logging. All other groups grant permissions to applications/features.Permissions are cached in memory when the user logs on to the application. Therefore, if permissions are changed, a user must exit and re-start the HealthRules Payer clients (Manager and Designer) to pick up the changed permissions.				askHE			Disclaimer					askHE utilizes generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and is intended to provide general information. metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are the User Window and its three tabs: User Profile, Member Of, and Audit Log. The User Profile tab displays information about the user, such as their contact information, effective dates, and other details. The Member Of tab lists the groups to which the user belongs. The Audit Log tab shows the activities and changes related to the user, including the user ID, date and time of actions, type of action, and additional comments. The entities mentioned in the section include the user, user groups, email address, start and termination dates, employee ID, organization name, external ID, Is Interactive checkbox, Externally Authenticated checkbox, log entries, user ID, action type, effective date, document type, reason, comment, IP address, and server name.

__data__.text: User WindowSkip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: User WindowThe User window displays when you click the User list panel on the left. The window consists of the user name field and the following three tabs allowing you to manage the user profiles, manage group assignments for users, and view the audit logs of the users.User Profile TabThe User Profile tab displays a summary of the user's information. This also includes contact information (e-mail address), effective dates, and other user information (employee ID, organization name, external ID) for the selected user.Section/FieldDescriptionPrimary NameThe primary name of the selected user.Contact InformationEmail Address - The email address of the selected user.Effective DatesStart Date - The date on which the user was added to the system.Termination Date - The date on which the user was terminated from the system.Other InformationEmployee ID - The employee identification number of the user.Organization Name - The name of the company to which the user belongs.External ID - Any other identification numbers associated with the user.Is Interactive - The checkbox is selected to send the user's transactions to a queue (the "Interactive Ready Queue") for immediate processing, rather than the assigned or default (non-interactive) queue where the user may have to wait for an extended period before the system can process the submitted transaction. For example, when a user submits an asynchronous transaction such as a claim edit to the queue and other jobs are already in the queue, the user may have to wait for a long period before the submitted transaction is processed by the system. If you want the particular user's jobs to be processed immediately, select the Is Interactive checkbox to send the job to the "Interactive Ready Queue" to process immediately.Note:  The Is Interactive checkbox is selected by default for externally authenticated users.Externally Authenticated - The Externally Authenticated checkbox is selected when a user is created and managed by an external provider such as LDAP, Active Directory, or other authentication provider and is not a HealthRules Payer user. It helps distinguish between HealthRules Payer users created and managed via HealthRules Administration Console and external users to prevent administrators from amending those external users. It helps facilitate central management of user accounts and groups.Note: When this checkbox is selected, the Add to Group, Remove From Group, and Change Password buttons on the toolbar are not available. You can remove the checkbox to indicate that the user is a HealthRules Payer user, not an externally authenticated, and enable the buttons on the toolbar. For more information,  see the HealthRules Payer Reduced Sign-On Guide.Member Of TabThe Member Of tab lists all groups to which a user belongs, including groups they are members through other groups granting indirect permissions.All users must inherit permissions from the “hcc_user” group to successfully log on to the system. The “hcc_user” group provides the required authentication permissions (see "Required HealthRules Users and Groups").Audit Log TabThe Audit Log tab lists activities related to the selected user.FieldDescriptionHide Log EntriesIf selected indicates that the log on entries are excluded from displaying on the log. Note: This does not apply to groups.UserIndicates the user ID of the user making the change or logging on. When the user entry is <WLS Kernal>, it indicates a web service action generated the log action.Entered Indicates the date and time of the user action.Action Indicates the type of action performed by the user. For example, create, amend, login, and failed authentication actions.Effective As OfThe date the change becomes effective in the system. This is the endorsement date version and only the latest version of the record is used. No ReprocessingThis is not applicable for user and group accounts.Reprocess As OfThis is not applicable for user and group accounts.Type Indicates the name of the HealthRules Payer document type.ReasonIndicates the reason for the action.CommentIndicates any additional comments added related to the action.IP AddressThe IP address from which the user logged on or attempted to log on.Server The server name from which the user logged on or attempted to log on.The following column is available via the column chooser:Portal TypeThis field reflects which type of portal user changed the record (Employer, Broker, Provider).				askHE			Disclaimer					askHE utilizes generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and is intended to provide general information. metadata.section_summary:
The key topics of the section "Business Segment Overview" are:

1. Definition of a business segment: It is a grouping of accounts with common business rules and characteristics, including HCC-like settings such as validation policies, operation and claim provisions, and carriers.

2. Overrides at the business segment level: The business segment rules and characteristics override the processing rules set at the Health Care Company (HCC) level for various aspects such as Account ID Generation Rule, Filing Limit Provision, Duplicate Detection Provision, and Payment Cycle.

3. Purpose of business segments: Business segments can be used for segregation of individual and group businesses for reporting and billing purposes, as well as for segregation of different states for multi-state carriers.

4. Shared components within business segments: Business segments in the same physical environment share code sets, benefit plan components, service definitions, and provider data.

The key entities mentioned in the section are:

1. Health Care Company (HCC): The level at which processing rules are set, which can be overridden by business segment rules.

2. Account ID Generation Rule: A processing rule that determines how account IDs are generated.

3. Filing Limit Provision: A processing rule that sets the time limit for filing claims.

4. Duplicate Detection Provision: A processing rule that identifies and handles duplicate claims.

5. Payment Cycle: A processing rule that determines the frequency and timing of claim payments.

6. Code sets: Shared sets of codes used within business segments.

7. Benefit plan components: Components of benefit plans that are shared within business segments.

8. Service definitions: Definitions of services provided within business segments.

9. Provider data: Data related to healthcare providers that is shared within business segments.

metadata.section_summary:
The key topics of the section "Post Payments and Allocations for Account Page" are creating payments, applying unallocated payments to open bills, funding request receivables, and funding request adjustments. It also discusses the ability to apply premium payables and negative adjustments for one plan to premium receivables for another plan, as well as applying payables across sub-accounts and billing categories. The section also mentions the ability to record binder payments and the system's evaluation of binder payments to determine if the subscription status should be set to "Active." 

The key entities mentioned in the section are payment entries, including payment number, payment date, receipt date, payment amount, payment type, and bill amount. It also discusses open bills, unallocated payments and adjustments, account name, benefit plan, premium payment ID, billing category, payment date, due date, payment age, allocated amount, bill total, balance, unallocated amount, type of unallocated item, account representative, account status, adjustment ID, bill number, payable ID, receivable ID, subscriber name, subscription ID, bill number, and funding request ID.

metadata.file_name: Post Payments and Allocations for Account Page

__data__.text: Post Payments and Allocations for Account Page Skip To Main ContentAccountSettingsLogoutplaceholderAccountSettingsLogoutFilter: All FilesSubmit Search This content helped me. This content didn't help me. PrintYou are here: Post Payments and Allocations for Account Page To display this page, on the Account View page, Billing tab, click the Payments /Allocations button. Use the Post Payments and Allocations for Account page to:Create payments Apply unallocated payments to open bills, funding request receivables, and funding request adjustments.If necessary, you can apply premium payables and negative adjustments for one plan to premium receivables for another plan. You can also apply payables across sub-accounts and billing categories. You can allocate the payments partially to the outstanding balances and allocate one payment towards multiple outstanding balances. The system appropriately tracks section-level and plan-level allocations. If your healthcare company has an administrative policy requiring a binder payment before a subscription can become active, you can record the binder payment here. Note that if the payment is a binder payment (the first premium payment ever for the plan selection, or the first premium payment after a break in coverage), the system will compare the Payment Amount to the Bill Amount. If the Bill Amount is not entered, or it is entered and is greater than the Payment Amount, the system will not change the subscription status to "Active." Only if the Bill Amount is entered, and is less than or equal to the Payment Amount, will the subscription status be set to "Active."For binder payments, HealthRules does not add multiple payments received to determine if the combined total equals the Bill Amount. The system only evaluates the first payment (binder) to determine if the binder payment is received and paid in full based on the Bill Amount and the Payment Amount.  Fields and Descriptions Fields/CommandsDescriptionsCreate Payment Entry Payment NumberEnter the number of the check (or the number of the electronic payment that was received.) Payment DateEnter the date of the payment. Receipt DateEnter the date the check/payment. was received. Payment AmountEnter the amount of the payment. Payment TypeSelect the user-defined payment type from the drop-down. For example, Check, EFT, Wire. Bill AmountThe Bill Amount may be set by the incoming EDI 820 transaction or entered by the user. See note regarding binder payments and Bill Amount on previous page.Open BillTo allocate to a specific open bill, select the bill from the drop-down. Auto AllocateTo automatically allocate this payment to open bills according to the business rules defined in the Health Care Company, select this checkbox. If you select this checkbox, and click the Submit button, the system first allocates this payment. If there are other outstanding unallocated payments, the system, will allocate them, if possible.Submit ButtonClick this button to submit the payment. The results will depend on whether or not you selected the auto-allocate checkbox. See the Auto Allocate field description above for additional information. Unallocated Payments and AdjustmentsAccount NameThe name of the account.Benefit PlanThe benefit plan associated with the billed account. Premium Payment IDThe payment ID of the premium payment.Payment NumberThe check number (or payment number) of the payment. Billing CategoryThe billing category associated with the bill. Payment AmountThe amount of the check/payment. Payment DateThe date of the payment.Due DateThe payment due date.Receipt DateThe date the payment was received. Payment AgeThe number of days since reciept date. To DateThe payment period to date.Allocated AmountThe amount which has been allocated to bills.Bill TotalThe total amount of the bill.BalanceThe current check balance for the account. Unallocated AmountThis is the amount of the payment that remains unallocated to an open bill.  It could be an over-payment that cannot yet be applied, as well.TypeThe type of unallocated item; Premium payment, Adjustment Credit, Credit Funding Adjustment, Funding Payable.Account RepresentativeThe representative assigned to the account.Account StatusThe current account status.Adjustment IDThe associated billing adjustment IDBill NumberThe associated bill number.Payable IDThe associated payable ID.Receivable IDThe associated receivable ID. Subscriber NameThe name of the subscriber. Subscription IDThe subscription ID.Apply ButtonTo apply an unallocated payment or adjustment to an open bill, select the item and click the Apply button. The Apply Payment page appears. Here you can allocate the Check Balance to open bills.Open Bills and Funding RequestsBill NumberThe bill number.Funding Request IDThe funding request ID.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are post payments and allocations for the account page. It provides information on the unallocated amount, types of unallocated items, account representative, account status, adjustment ID, bill number, payable ID, receivable ID, subscriber name, and subscription ID. It also explains how to apply unallocated payments or adjustments to open bills. Additionally, the section covers open bills and funding requests, including bill number, funding request ID, funding request adjustment ID, funding request receivable ID, cycle ID, premium refund ID, account name, benefit plan name, billing category, billing date, due date, to date, bill total, net allocated amount, net balance, and sent date.

__data__.text: Unallocated AmountThis is the amount of the payment that remains unallocated to an open bill.  It could be an over-payment that cannot yet be applied, as well.TypeThe type of unallocated item; Premium payment, Adjustment Credit, Credit Funding Adjustment, Funding Payable.Account RepresentativeThe representative assigned to the account.Account StatusThe current account status.Adjustment IDThe associated billing adjustment IDBill NumberThe associated bill number.Payable IDThe associated payable ID.Receivable IDThe associated receivable ID. Subscriber NameThe name of the subscriber. Subscription IDThe subscription ID.Apply ButtonTo apply an unallocated payment or adjustment to an open bill, select the item and click the Apply button. The Apply Payment page appears. Here you can allocate the Check Balance to open bills.Open Bills and Funding RequestsBill NumberThe bill number.Funding Request IDThe funding request ID. You can use the Funding Request ID to group funding receivable and funding adjustments by funding request.Funding Request Adjustment IDThe ID of the associated adjustment. These include open debit funding adjustments.Funding Request Receivable IDThe ID of the associated receivable. These include open and partially allocated funding receivables.Cycle IDThe ID to identify the funding cycle ID of all open and unallocated funding entities.Note: The funding adjustments or funding payables can only be allocated to funding receivables and debit funding adjustments. Also, you can only allocate payments, payables, or credit adjustments to funding receivables or debit adjustments within the same payment cycle. Allocation across funding cycles manually or through auto-allocation is not allowed. Premium Refund IDThe premium refund ID.Account NameThe name of the account with the open bill.Benefit Plan NameThe name of the benefit plan associated with the bill. Billing CategoryThe billing category associated with the bill (for example, "Premium"). Billing DateThe billing date of the bill. Due DateThe date the bill is due to be paid.  To DateThe last day of the billing period for this bill.Bill TotalThe bill total. Net Allocated AmountThe net allocated amount on the bill. Net BalanceThe current bill balance, adjusted as payments are allocated to the bill. Sent DateThe date the bill was sent.				askHE			Disclaimer					askHE utilizes generative artificial intelligence (GAI) and is intended to provide general information. metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are users in HealthRules Payer and their roles and permissions. The section explains that a user is a person who uses any of the HealthRules Payer applications and must have an account. Users can be individuals or in specific roles, and they must be assigned a unique username and password combination. Each user must also be a member of a group to have the necessary permissions to access the application. The section also mentions the required HealthRules users and groups.

The key topics of the section are groups and user access control. A group is a record containing a list of users and other groups, and it helps control user access to the system through the assignment of permissions. Groups can belong to one or more other groups, forming a hierarchical chain. The section also mentions the use of groups to assign a set of permissions for similar types of users. The entities mentioned in the section are users, groups, and permissions.

The key topics of this section are permissions in HealthRules Payer, the types of permissions (direct and indirect), and the different categories of permissions available. The entities mentioned include user groups, user access to actions, claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are searching for a record to edit or view and using sorting and filtering options. The key entities mentioned are the Search page, search criteria, Results pane, record, Edit dialog, and View dialog.

The key topics of the section are how to import data into HealthRules Manager from a flat file and the steps involved in the import process. The key entities mentioned in the section are HealthRules Manager, flat file, Subscription View page, Import Document Confirmation dialog, Specify As Of Date dialog, Reason Code, Edit window, and View Window.

The key topics of this section are permissions in HealthRules Payer, the types of permissions (direct and indirect), and the different categories of permissions available. The entities mentioned include user groups, user access to actions, claims processing actions, reports, message codes, accounts, and products.

The key topics of the section are the User Window and its three tabs: User Profile, Member Of, and Audit Log. The User Profile tab displays information about the user, such as their contact information, effective dates, and other details. The Member Of tab lists the groups to which the user belongs. The Audit Log tab shows the activities and changes related to the user, including the user ID, date and time of actions, type of action, and additional comments. The entities mentioned in the section include the user, user groups, email address, start and termination dates, employee ID, organization name, external ID, Is Interactive checkbox, Externally Authenticated checkbox, log entries, user ID, action type, effective date, document type, reason, comment, IP address, and server name.

metadata.section_summary: The key topics of the section are adding a group to one or more existing groups and inheriting permissions from those groups. The key entities mentioned are groups and permissions.

The key topics of the section are "Look Up Permissions" and "Data Maintenance Code Look Up." The section explains that users need appropriate view permissions to look up records using features such as the Search icon, drop-down lists, or grids. It also mentions specific document types that require group access permissions in addition to view permissions. Additionally, the section discusses the view permissions required to access data maintenance codes such as Diagnosis, Provider Taxonomy, Service Modifier Code, and Place of Service Code.
The key topics of the section are secure login and the requirements for accessing the site. The entities mentioned are modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) and JavaScript.

The key topics of the section are secure login, browser requirements, JavaScript requirement, and enabling JavaScript. The key entities mentioned are modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) and the website or page that requires secure login.

The key topics of the section "Business Segment Overview" are:

1. Definition of a business segment: It is a grouping of accounts with common business rules and characteristics, including HCC-like settings such as validation policies, operation and claim provisions, and carriers.

2. Overrides at the business segment level: The business segment rules and characteristics override the processing rules set at the Health Care Company (HCC) level for various aspects such as Account ID Generation Rule, Filing Limit Provision, Duplicate Detection Provision, and Payment Cycle.

3. Purpose of business segments: Business segments can be used for segregation of individual and group businesses for reporting and billing purposes, as well as for segregation of different states for multi-state carriers.

4. Shared components within business segments: Business segments in the same physical environment share code sets, benefit plan components, service definitions, and provider data.

The key entities mentioned in the section are:

1. Health Care Company (HCC): The level at which processing rules are set, which can be overridden by business segment rules.

2. Account ID Generation Rule: A processing rule that determines how account IDs are generated.

3. Filing Limit Provision: A processing rule that sets the time limit for filing claims.

4. Duplicate Detection Provision: A processing rule that identifies and handles duplicate claims.

5. Payment Cycle: A processing rule that determines the frequency and timing of claim payments.

6. Code sets: Shared sets of codes used within business segments.

7. Benefit plan components: Components of benefit plans that are shared within business segments.

8. Service definitions: Definitions of services provided within business segments.

9. Provider data: Data related to healthcare providers that is shared within business segments.

The key topics of the section are creating a broker record and entering required and optional information for the record. The key entities mentioned are the broker, broker ID, tax ID, primary correspondence address, and validation errors.

The key topics of the section are Shared Billing Rates and how they are created in HealthRules Manager Financials. The section explains that Shared Billing Rates are created similarly to other billing rates, but with additional information such as a name, description, coverage tier set, and associated template. These shared billing rates are used to build identical rates across multiple accounts when the Benefit Plan Wizard is run. The section also includes a disclaimer about the accuracy of the content generated by askHE, an AI-powered chatbot.

The key topics of the section are the Apply Payment Page and the fields and commands on that page. The entities mentioned include the account ID and name, check number and balance, bill number, funding request ID and adjustment ID, premium refund ID, benefit plan name, billing category, receivable ID, adjustment ID, due date, total amount of the bill, and payment amount.
